Reported by Geert Vermeiren:

Hi,

Same problem occurs on my machine. I'm running linux-gtk(2.4.x) on amd64. In
addition to the exception in the original report, I get an error dialog when
clicking the Help preferences:
"Could not accept changes - The currently displayed page contains invalid 
values". 
After activating another prefs page, then re-activating the help prefs, the 
page
appears, "The selection determines..." but no controls are available on the
page. Both 'mozilla' and 'firefox' are available as browsers on my system.

Geert:
What is your linux distribution?
Which Mozilla is installed? (you can get the version by typing about: in the 
Mozilla URL entry.

Are you using the 64 bit version of Eclipse or the regular 32 bit Linux GTK 
Eclipse?

Thanks!

If you need to get things working, here what to do so that the Browser does 
not show up:

csh
setenv MOZILLA_FIVE_HOME EMPTY
eclipse

This will cause the SWT Browser to not find any Mozilla build. And Eclipse 
should be usable to you.

To help us understand more:

1. Which build of Eclipse are you using? Go to Help > About Eclipse Platform > 
build id

2. Can you paste the output of the following:
- start Mozilla
- type the following in the Mozilla URL bar (without the 
quotes): "build.config"
Just to verify it is a GTK2 64 build.


This is weird. nsEmbedString should be in the swt-mozilla.jar under the 
org.eclipse.swt.gtk64 fragment. In case you were running 3.0, can you try a 
recent integration build (today's one for example)? I would have expected a 
different kind of error.

build-id: I20050202-0800

Typing build.config at the url of mozilla just says 'www.build.config' not found :-)

about: in the url gives me
Mozilla/5.0 (X11; U; Linux x86_64; en-US; rv:1.7.3) Gecko/20041020
Pretty sure it's the correct version as it was installed with Fedora

Anyway, I tried looking at the error-log, clicking the button from the eclipse
about-box. Guess what? Mozilla opened showing me .log (apparently it uses
another way of opening mozilla)

Thanks. Sorry, it was: "about:buildconfig", not build.config.

To be able to use Eclipse until this issue is resolved, please do this:
csh
setenv MOZILLA_FIVE_HOME EMPTY
eclipse

That causes the SWT Browser widget to not find/embed your Mozilla and to not 
throw that exception.

> apparently it uses another way of opening mozilla)
Yes in that case it's launching an external Mozilla.

Indeed, the setenv thing does the trick.

--without-system-nspr --with-system-zlib --with-system-png --with-system-jpeg
--enable-default-toolkit=gtk2 --disable-freetype2 --enable-xft --enable-pango
--mandir=/usr/share/man

Additionally, after setting the environment thingie, the help-prefs page is back
to normal too. I see 3 external browsers (mozilla, firefox which I installed
manually, and 'custom'). Without setenv the list was empty.
*** Bug 86760 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***
*** Bug 88391 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***

Fixed. AMD64 Browser will simply throw a NO MORE HANDLES, Browser is not 
supported for 3.1 on that platform. This will let the build work fine without 
the Browser functionality.

The swt-mozilla native library is no longer built for AMD64. The problem is 
that we currently need to build against Mozilla 1.4 to be upward compatible, 
however there are no standard out of the box Mozilla 1.4 64 bit compliant 
sources. At the moment every distribution has their own set of patches to 
workaround 64 bit issues. As an experiment, I tried to build our library 
against a 1.7.5 patched from Gentoo but that has proven to be causing trouble 
and not very useful since it was not working with most other 64 bit Mozilla 
builds.
64 bit Browser support can be revisited if a future version of the Browser is 
implemented on top of GtkMozembed or when major Linux distributions switched 
to a standard 64 bit 1.7 version of Mozilla.

How about some instructions for those of us willing to brave these issues? I
tried doing this myself. Here is what I did:

cd
~/eclipse-3.1/plugins/org.eclipse.platform.source.linux.gtk.x86_64_3.1.0/src/org.eclipse.swt.gtk.linux.x86_64_3.1.0/

mkdir src
cd src
unzip ../src.zip
vi make_linux.mak

A the diff with the changes:

--- src/make_linux.mak  2005-05-13 14:40:30.000000000 -0700
+++ crap/make_linux.mak 2005-05-19 00:13:01.725435072 -0700
@@ -50,6 +50,7 @@
 # Uncomment for Native Stats tool
 #NATIVE_STATS = -DNATIVE_STATS
 
+MOZILLA_FIVE_HOME=/opt/mozilla64
 MOZILLACFLAGS = -O \
        -DXPCOM_GLUE=1 \
        -DMOZILLA_STRICT_API=1 \
@@ -62,6 +63,10 @@
        -I./ \
        -I$(JAVA_HOME)/include \
        -I$(JAVA_HOME)/include/linux \
+       -I$(MOZILLA_FIVE_HOME)/include/xpcom \
+       -I$(MOZILLA_FIVE_HOME)/include/nspr \
+       -I$(MOZILLA_FIVE_HOME)/include/embed_base \
+       -I$(MOZILLA_FIVE_HOME)/include/string \
        ${GECKO_INCLUDES} \
        ${SWT_PTR_CFLAGS}
        
@@ -86,7 +91,7 @@
 LIBS = -shared -fpic -s
 
 
-all: make_swt make_atk make_gnome make_awt
+all: make_swt make_atk make_gnome make_awt make_mozilla
 
 #
 # SWT libs

make -f make_linux.mak
cp libswt*.so ~/eclipse-3.1/configuration/org.eclipse.osgi/bundles/41/1/.cp/

(It seems eclipse 3.1 extracts the .so files from a jar and creates an arbitrary
directory to put them in. This is that directory on my machine, so I put these
files here)

I then run eclipse with MOZILLA_FIVE_HOME=/opt/mozilla64 (the default mozilla on
my machine is 32 bit. I keep a 64 bit mozilla here for eclipse only). I get this:

java.lang.UnsatisfiedLinkError:
/home/primus/eclipse-3.1/configuration/org.eclipse.osgi/bundles/41/1/.cp/libswt-pi-gtk-3135.so:
/home/primus/eclipse-3.1/configuration/org.eclipse.osgi/bundles/41/1/.cp/libswt-pi-gtk-3135.so:
undefined symbol: XTestFakeButtonEvent

If I don't replace the two library files that come from the eclipse jar file, I
get this:

org.eclipse.swt.SWTError: No more handles (java.lang.UnsatisfiedLinkError: no
swt-mozilla-gtk-3135 in java.library.path)

So I then do a bunch of stracing and try to find where it's looking for the said
file. It actually finds it in the bundles/41/1/.cp directory, but refuses to use
it. I then copy it to /opt/mozilla64, and symlink it to libswt-mozilla-gtk.so,
and it find it. Which then yields:

org.eclipse.swt.SWTError: No more handles (java.lang.UnsatisfiedLinkError:
/opt/mozilla64/libswt-mozilla-gtk-3135.so:
/opt/mozilla64/libswt-mozilla-gtk-3135.so: undefined symbol: _ZN4nsID5ParseEPKc)

This is in libxpcom.so, which is found in /opt/mozilla64. I then for this to be
loaded with LD_PRELOAD. This gets me this:

org.eclipse.swt.SWTError: No more handles (java.lang.UnsatisfiedLinkError:
/opt/mozilla64/libswt-mozilla-gtk-3135.so:
/opt/mozilla64/libswt-mozilla-gtk-3135.so: undefined symbol: NS_InitEmbedding)

Seeing the pattern here? It seems this libswt-mozilla-gtk can't or won't resolve
its dependent libraries. Anyhow, that symbol is found in libgtkembedmoz.so. I
try to LD_PRELOAD this too, which then causes java to simply crash.

I guess I'd just like to know what I did wrong, if anything. How can I force the
libswt-mozilla-gtk.so to resolve its libraries? Is there a way to do this?
Should I just give up? I'd _really_ like the embedded browser in eclipse 3.1 on
amd64.

BTW, the embeded browser in 3.1M6 on Linux amd64 works fine for me.

Thoughts?

Also, is there a bug report report to track the issue of getting a stable 
Mozilla build against which we can compile?  This bug report is closed but the 
issue is not fully resolved.

This bug report is a bit confusing.  All of the stack traces on this bug are for
NoClassDefFound errors, which indicates a problem in the Java side and not with
the compiled mozilla code or the version of mozilla on the target machine.  This
indicates a bug either with the build, or with the class loader.  I believe that
these problems are resolved by the new build strategy for 3.1 which puts all of
the SWT Java code in a single jar.

Since:

  1. It is a pain to build the mozilla library for amd64 users that want it
  2. There are no reported crashes from incompatible mozilla builds
  3. amd64 is still an "early access" platform for Eclipse
  4. Users are asking for embedded mozilla support
  5. It's easy to disable if it is causing problems (unset MOZILLA_FIVE_HOME)

I think we should just re-enable it in our builds.
*** Bug 96405 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***
Please re-enabled for RC2. Request done per Billy Biggs request on IRC.

I have added the mozilla library for AMD64.
Unfortunately, I did not make it in time for the warm up RC2 build at noon 
today but it will be in for the next build - which will be at 4PM today.

I have compiled the eclipse 3.1 final on amd64 against mozilla 1.7.8 and the
embedded browser works nicely after patching a few files here and there (all
required changes have been entered as bugs here).

Before compiling remember to delete all the .so files so that you can be sure
that the ones distributed with the source package are not used.

Tested and works on Fedora Core 4 Java 1.5.0_04 x86_64,  stock mozilla 1.7.10
RPMS, and eclipse 3.1  Only had to install the compat-libstdc++33 for x86_64 to
provide libstdc++.so.5.  

just set 
export MOZILLA_FIVE_HOME=/usr/lib64/mozilla-1.7.10
export LD_LIBRARY_PATH="$MOZILLA_FIVE_HOME:$LD_LIBRARY_PATH"

in my eclipse wrapper startup script.

I'm seeing 3.2.2 crashes with

/usr/bin/java: symbol lookup error: /opt/eclipse64/configuration/org.eclipse.osgi/bundles/518/1/.cp/libswt-mozilla-gcc3-gtk-3236.so: undefined symbol: NS_InitEmbedding

re: comment 19

a fix is available for this, see https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=174547#c8
Closing, this was fixed quite a while ago.
